content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

Given my moderately cautious nature and preference for security and predictability, I would choose the strategy that ensures a relatively stable income while minimizing potential losses. In this game, if I always pick R (Rock), my payoff for correct guesses is 45$, which is the maximum possible reward in each round. However, if my opponent picks B (Scissors) when I pick R, I get nothing. This scenario happens once for every two times my opponent chooses B.

On the other hand, if I always pick B (Scissors), my payoff for correct guesses is 12$ per round, which is significantly less than the 45$ I would earn in each round by picking R when my opponent picks Scissors. However, in this case, I would only lose 0$ in each of the instances where my opponent chooses Rock instead of Scissors (which happens once for every two times they choose Rock).

Since I prefer stability and predictability, I would rather accept a slightly lower reward per round but minimize potential losses by choosing B (Scissors) in this game. This strategy will also prevent me from having zero income in too many rounds.

So, my choice is {B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.

In the next round, I would continue with the same strategy of choosing B (Scissors), as it aligns with my preference for stability and minimizing potential losses. Since my opponent also chose B in the previous round, we both will earn 12$ again in this round.

It's important to note that our cumulative earnings after one round would be the same (12$ each), but if we were playing a longer game, the differences in the long-term outcomes could become more significant depending on our opponent's behavior and the randomness of their choices. However, given my cautious nature and preference for predictability, I will stick with the B strategy for now.
